entry.title: Staff your SAP Cloud ERP Enterprise Projects with the right Employees
entry.content:
Effective project and resource management is crucial for companies to deliver successful projects. Organizations running Enterprise Projects and/or Customer Projects in SAP Cloud ERP have the possibility to leverage SAP Project and Resource Management to optimize the project success. Resource Management is a process which spans normally over the complete lifetime of a project, starting with the initial finding and assignment of people, doing the continuous staffing forecasts and handling conflicts like substituting people. This blog provides an overview of how SAP Project and Resource Management facilitates these different staffing capabilities during the project life cycle of Enterprise Projects in SAP Cloud ERP.

Introduction:

Enterprise projects in SAP Cloud ERP   can be used to manage different kinds of projects in different industries. Examples are:

    • Overhead projects: for example, administrative projects or projects for research and development,
    • Investment projects: for example, projects to develop or maintain physical assets,
    • Projects with revenue: for example, engineer-to-order projects,
    • Statistical projects: can be used for certain reporting needs, without carry actual costs itself

Details about the different Project Types are documented in the following blog:
The two project control possibilities in SAP S/4HA... - SAP Community

 

Optimizing Resource Allocation:

Even in a simple project scenario, where an enterprise project merely serves as a cost collector without a formal project structure, managing resources is still required. Team members can log hours against the project, so optimizing resource allocation is crucial. To do this, you need clear visibility of available and skilled resources

Resource Management capability of SAP Project and Resource Management covers the following key aspects:

  • Transparency: Overview of projects people are working on and identification of conflicts
  • Reduce time to staff for Projects:
    • Staffing: Find available and skilled people and staff persons as requested and consider their availability
    • AI-assisted skill matching: overcome challenges like outdated employee profiles and reviewing many profiles manually
  • Increase staffing accuracy: Project workers can directly maintain their forecasts based on when they are needed for a project
  • Increase time-booking quality: SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Timesheet worklist includes projects on which person is staffed
  • Single source of truth: the close integration between resource management information with the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Project data provides synchronized data
  • SAP unified User Experience
  • Simple to adapt 

 

Basic scenarios and concepts:

SAP Project and Resource Management is a SaaS offering on SAP Business Technology Platform. Once the subscription is in place a scope item facilitates the setup.

Users can choose if resource management apps for business users should directly run in the SAP Cloud ERP Launchpad, e.g. Project Managers using the Project-related apps can also directly see the resource management apps they need.

 

Setup:

To proceed with the setup the following sources contain more details.
Administration Guide:
https://help.sap.com/docs/PPRM_OD/542f4545bc9d4ecd80bc3a0a6913a735/434f2ec669444cc98583a1c4eadca05a.html

The blog ‚ÄúSetup Resource Management Capability in SAP Project and Resource Management‚Äù provides a summary how to proceed by setting up the integration:
https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/setup-resource-management-capability-in-sap-projects-and-resource/ba-p/13999829

 

Process:

Harmonizing staffing with project setup and milestone planning can reduce Backoffice efforts and allow people to focus on what is needed to deliver projects successfully instead of spending effort in maintaining consistent information across different sources.  

The process starts in SAP Cloud ERP when a Resource demand is created:

 


Screen shows the resource demand defined in the Enterprise Project

Once the Enterprise Project Integration is setup for SAP Cloud ERP ‚Äúhuman resource‚Äù demands create the Resource Requests in Resource Management.

The process is explained along the most used apps in this blog.

1. Manage Resource Requests (Role: Project Manager)

Resource Request contains the need for a specific resource and is normally being refined by a user, e.g. Project Manager. During the refinement information about needed skills, scope description, requested resource organization are added. Once the request is complete the Project Manager can ‚Äúpublish‚Äù the request, so it becomes visible to the Resource Managers. No need to send additional information via email and capture the information directly where it is needed.


Screen shows the resource request which was published and includes ‚ÄúSAP Cloud ERP‚Äù as a required skill

 

2. Staff Resource Requests (Role: Resource Manager)

Resource Managers review the request and start now with the search of candidates. Availability and Skill matching are performed and available candidates identified. Resource Manager can propose or directly staff one or multiple candidates:

  • Proposing a candidate, allows Project Manager to accept / decline candidates
  • Soft booking is not yet confirmed staffing and only visible in resource management, while Hard booking is a confirmed booking type and people will see staffing in the SAP Cloud ERP timesheet app.
  • Forward requests, in case no suitable candidates are identified a request can be forwarded to another organization

Learn more how the AI-Assisted Advanced Skill Matching facilitates the search of skilled candidates check:
Unlock Efficient Resource Management with AI in SA... - SAP Community


Screen shows the matching candidates list and the Advanced Skill Match for Lilian Blair ‚Äì Lilian is being assigned by using the ‚ÄúQuick Assign‚Äù feature

 

3. Manage Resource Utilization (Role: Resource Manager)

Provides transparency how people are utilized, visualizes conflicts of over / under bookings and shows directly on which projects and roles people are working.

Resource Managers can also create, change and move assignments in order to resolve conflicts and adjust the planning.


Screen shows a list of filtered employees which includes Lilian Blair and her staffing for the Project Expert role

 

4. My Assignments (Role: Project Team Member)

Once employees are staffed and have the needed authorization, they can maintain a staffing forecast means they can adjust in which weeks they work how many hours on a project. This allows them to refine and balance between different project assignments and align their involvement along with the planned project milestones, considering planned absences etc.

The updated information is afterwards visible for Resource- and Project Managers to ensure everyone has the updated information.



Screen shows mobile view of Lilian‚Äôs ‚ÄúMy Assignment‚Äù app.

Staffed hours and candidates will be visible in SAP Cloud ERP. The Enterprise Project demand will get directly information about the assigned people and hours. This helps to bring up staffing information in the employee‚Äôs timesheet worklist to simplify timesheet capturing and reduce the time to find the right project.

 

Summary:

Resources assignments and staffed hours are kept in synch between the SAP Cloud ERP and Resource Management, which ensures that all users have the same view on resource demands and what is being staffed.

SAP Project and Resource Management supports you by gaining transparency on your resource utilization situation with a fully integrated and embedded into the SAP User Experience scenario.

To learn more and to explore Resource Management in SAP Project and Resource Management you can find more information and access the free trial under:

https://www.sap.com/prm

 

Companies running Customer Projects in SAP Cloud ERP can also consult the following blog:
https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/overcoming-challenges-in-staffing-customer-projects-with-sap-project-and/ba-p/13748436

entry.title: Re: Storage Location as MRP area
entry.content:
If the storage location is not there in PR, then, it could be due to the following reasons

  • If the sales order for the FG material doesn‚Äôt pass the storage location correctly to the raw material demand, the system defaults to plant-level planning. This often happens when the BOM or routing doesn‚Äôt specify the storage location for the component. So, if needed, check with PP team also on MRP related settings.
  • In MRP1, the MRP Area assignment must be active. In MRP4, check the Storage Location MRP Indicator‚Äîit should be set to 2 (Sloc-level planning). If this is missing, the system may revert to plant-level planning even during Sloc-level MRP runs.
  • If the special procurement key or source list doesn‚Äôt specify a storage location, the PR will be created without one‚Äîeven if MRP was run at the Sloc level.

entry.title: Re: Unable to see the log during Invoice cancellation
entry.content:
Hi,

It seems you are encountering an issue with the custom logic implemented in the BADI SD_BIL_FLEX_CANCELLATION Sales - Flexible Billing Document Cancellation for invoice cancellation based on the IRN status. The error message ‚ÄòInvoice cannot be cancelled please cancel the IRN first‚Äô is visible during debugging but not in the VF11 app, where you see a blank log screen.

You may try to add a message to log to help you better debugging. 

CLASS-METHODS log_message
IMPORTING
!iv_msgty TYPE symsgty
!iv_msgid TYPE symsgid
!iv_msgno TYPE symsgno
!iv_msgv1 TYPE any OPTIONAL
!iv_msgv2 TYPE any OPTIONAL
!iv_msgv3 TYPE any OPTIONAL
!iv_msgv4 TYPE any OPTIONAL.

METHOD log_message.
DATA: ls_message TYPE bapireturn.
ls_message-type = iv_msgty.
ls_message-id = iv_msgid.
ls_message-number = iv_msgno.
ls_message-message_v1 = iv_msgv1.
ls_message-message_v2 = iv_msgv2.
ls_message-message_v3 = iv_msgv3.
ls_message-message_v4 = iv_msgv4.
APPEND ls_message TO messages.
ENDMETHOD.

Best regards, Dequan Xu

entry.title: API to download attachments of Projects
entry.content:
Dear Team,

I am trying to download attachments of projects through API so I have enabled communication arrangement with scenario, SAP_COM_0308. But I don't understand how to use this API to get attachment. Can you please suggest us how to fulfill our requirement?


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: API to download attachments of Projects
entry.content:
In the communication scenario Enterprise Project Integration (SAP_COM_0308), you can use the generic Attachments service (API_CV_ATTACHMENT_SRV) to manage attachments. Please follow below steps: 

1. Call GET method with operation GetAllOriginals to retrieve the metadata of the attachment associated with the project.

  • For enterprise project, use BusinessObjectTypeName = '/S4PPM/PRJ' and LinkedSAPObjectKey = '<UUID for project> or <UUID for WBS element>'
  • For professional services project, use BusinessObjectTypeName = '/CPD/EP' and LinkedSAPObjectKey = '<external ID for project>'
  • For professional services project element, use BusinessObjectTypeName = '/CPD/PFP' and LinkedSAPObjectKey = '<external ID for work package>'

Sample request URL for professional services work package:
GET <host>/sap/opu/odata/sap/API_CV_ATTACHMENT_SRV/GetAllOriginals?BusinessObjectTypeName='/CPD/PFP'&LinkedSAPObjectKey='<external ID for work package> '

The following properties can be found in response body:
<d:DocumentInfoRecordDocType>xxx</d:DocumentInfoRecordDocType>
<d:DocumentInfoRecordDocNumber>xxxxxxxxx</d:DocumentInfoRecordDocNumber>
<d:DocumentInfoRecordDocVersion>xx</d:DocumentInfoRecordDocVersion>
<d:DocumentInfoRecordDocPart>xxx</d:DocumentInfoRecordDocPart>
<d:LogicalDocument>xxxxxxxxx</d:LogicalDocument>
<d:ArchiveDocumentID>xxxxxxxxx</d:ArchiveDocumentID>
<d:LinkedSAPObjectKey>xxxxxxxxx</d:LinkedSAPObjectKey>
<d:BusinessObjectTypeName>xxxxxxxxx</d:BusinessObjectTypeName>

2. Use the properties retrieved from step 1 to call GET method with entity AttachmentContentSet to download the attachment content.

Sample request URL:
GET <host>/sap/opu/odata/sap/API_CV_ATTACHMENT_SRV/AttachmentContentSet(DocumentInfoRecordDocType='xxx',DocumentInfoRecordDocNumber='xxxxxxxxx',DocumentInfoRecordDocPart='xxx',DocumentInfoRecordDocVersion='xx',LogicalDocument='xxxxxxxxx',ArchiveDocumentID='xxxxxxxxx',LinkedSAPObjectKey='xxxxxxxxx',BusinessObjectTypeName='xxxxx')/$value

entry.title: Re: The E in Event-Driven Architecture: Introducing SAP‚Äôs new Event-Add for ERP
entry.content:
Hi @Cocquerel ,

currently the differences are in respect to connectivity (via AEM) and to pricing. In future the intention is to add features that would be unique to the Event Add-On.

In respect to the details of the pricing the SAP Discovery Center is the place. I assume you have looked up the number there, and this is what I would recommend. It seems in the right range.

Let me try to help you with a few statements though that will make it easier to put the pricing in context:

  • You do pay for activated AEM brokers - you do activate a broker for use with the add-on in AEM.
  • You can connect several backends with add-ons installed to an AEM broker (e.g. an ECC and an S/4HANA against a single broker)
  • There is no differentiation between productive, test or dev brokers. So dev or test brokers are not free of charge. As said, it is the activations on AEM brokers that count, not the number of installed add-ons.
  • The pricing is tiered as you can see in Discovery Center. 

Hope this helps for now. I understand that we need to provide reference architectures and pricing examples as part of this blog series.

Best,

Karsten

entry.title: Why SAP ISA-M Still Matters ‚Äì A Strategic Foundation for Modern Integration
entry.content:
In the era of APIs, hybrid landscapes, and cloud-native development, it's easy to assume that methodologies like SAP ISA-M (Integration Solution Advisory Methodology) are outdated. But the truth is: ISA-M is more relevant than ever. It remains a strategic compass for defining and implementing integration architectures that are sustainable, business-aligned, and tool-agnostic.

 

üîç What is SAP ISA-M?

SAP ISA-M is a structured methodology that helps enterprises define their integration strategy, classify integration use cases, and select the right technologies and governance models. It supports decision-making across cloud, hybrid, and on-premise landscapes ‚Äì regardless of whether you‚Äôre using SAP Integration Suite, SAP Advanced Event Mesh, or third-party platforms.

üîë Why ISA-M Still Matters Today

  1. Strategic Guidance for Cloud Transformation

ISA-M is widely used during S/4HANA and RISE with SAP transformations to assess legacy middleware (e.g., PI/PO) and design modern, API- and event-driven target architectures.

  1. Technology-Agnostic by Design

ISA-M is not tied to specific products. It provides a framework for integration strategy, which remains valid even as tools evolve ‚Äì from SAP Process Orchestration to SAP Integration Suite and beyond.

  1. Use Case-Driven Approach

By analyzing integration needs across five integration styles (e.g., process integration, data integration, event-driven integration), ISA-M helps teams design purposeful and scalable architectures.

  1. Connecting Business and IT

The methodology fosters collaboration between business owners, architects, and integration teams ‚Äì ensuring that integration becomes a business enabler, not just a technical necessity.

 

Where ISA-M is Used Today

‚úÖ Cloud Transformations & RISE with SAP

‚úÖ Modernization of Legacy Interfaces

‚úÖ Enablement & Governance Models

It outlines the phases in a modernization journey‚ÄîReview, Scope and Define Use Cases‚Äîand shows how to transition towards a future-ready, hybrid integration platform.

  • Assess Integration Strategy
  • Review Existing Integration Architecture
  • Scope and Define Best Practices and Target Architecture
  • Give power to the people

 

üöÄ Outlook: What‚Äôs Next for ISA-M?

üîß 1. ISA-M in INTAS ‚Äì SAP Integration Assessment Service

SAP‚Äôs INTAS (Integration Assessment Service) is a structured offering to help customers evaluate and modernize their integration landscape. ISA-M provides the core methodology behind this service:

  • Assessment of legacy and custom interfaces
  • Mapping use cases to modern SAP Integration Suite capabilities
  • Tailored modernization roadmap aligned to Clean Core principles

With INTAS, organizations benefit from a guided modernization plan that is both strategic and executable.

I will give you some more insights in on of our upcoming Integration Modernization expert sessions: https://events.sap.com/expertsession-isam/en_us/home.html

üîó 2. ISA-M and the SAP Integrated Toolchain

The SAP Integrated Toolchain for Modernization Projects combines multiple SAP tools and services, such as:

  • SAP Cloud ALM
  • SAP Signavio
  • SAP LeanIX
  • SAP WalkMe
  • SAP BTP ( with our focus on Integration Suite)

We us ISA-M acts as a strategic layer below the toolchain, ensuring that all activities ‚Äì from modeling to implementation ‚Äì follow a consistent integration strategy. For example:

  • LeanIX is the central tool for your overall Enterprise Architecture  ‚Üí ISA-M will help to control technologies and applications along the concept and to establish a government model
  • Signavio is used to model business processes ‚Üí ISA-M helps derive integration patterns
  • SAP Integration Suite itself can be used to integrate the toolchain (itself) ‚Üí ISA-M ensures style and governance fit, e.g. usage of SAP Advanced Event Mesh in combination with LeanIX Webhooks.

ISA-M connects the dots, providing strategic continuity across the entire toolchain.

We are currently working out an Integration Modernization expert which will give the required insights how you can implement it. Stay tune and follow our journey here https://events.sap.com/eur-sap-integration-modernization-expert-sessions/en_us/home.html

You would like to practice (e.g. with Integration content)? Just let me know.

üßº  3. ISA-M and Clean Core

Clean Core is one of the key guiding principles in SAP‚Äôs modernization strategy. But a Clean Core isn‚Äôt just about avoiding modifications ‚Äì it‚Äôs about separating business logic from system logic and creating modular, scalable architectures.

Here‚Äôs how ISA-M supports a Clean Core approach:

  • Recommends using APIs, events, and standardized integration styles
  • Avoids hard-coded dependencies between systems
  • Encourages centralized governance and reuse of services

By following ISA-M, companies are not just modernizing their interfaces ‚Äì they are actively cleaning their core.

 We hosted a first session how ISA-M can help you to ensure a clean-core approach Find the recording here: https://dam.sap.com/mac/app/e/video/embed/vAemLss?ltr=a&rc=10&doi=SAP1206809&includeSapBrandedWraper=true&includeRelatedAssets=true

 

‚úÖ Final Thoughts

Integration is no longer just a technical challenge ‚Äì it‚Äôs a strategic business discipline. And while the tools and technologies evolve, the need for a methodical, business-aligned integration strategy remains constant.

That‚Äôs why ISA-M continues to be a critical success factor for integration modernization, clean core transformation, and cloud-centric architectures.

Whether you're just starting your transformation journey or reviewing an existing landscape, ISA-M gives you the structure, language, and clarity to do it right.

üëâ Explore more:

  • ISA-M GitHub Repository
  • ISA-M Mission in SAP Discovery Center

 You need support? Send us a mail SAP Integration Modernization <integration.modernization@sap.com>

entry.title: In SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, How to declare VAT on cash basis?

Dear
I wondered if somebody from your team could help us on an S4HANA public cloud finance question by pointing us in the right direction.

 

Our customer as 3 subsidiaries in Germany. They make VAT declaration on accrual.

Only 1 entity in Germany wants to make VAT declaration on cash.

 

Is this possible?

 

We are looking for a functionality which would generate VAT report in Germany based on payments. It should be called VAT on cash basis method, when you report your tax only in case it was already paid.

 

So the obligation to report VAT is further determined by the fact we have a payment in system related to invoice or other transaction where tax was posted.

 

It is an opposite to accrual VAT method, where tax must be reported immediately upon invoice posting regardless of its payment.

Thank you in advance.
Best regards,

entry.title: üöÄ Mastering SAP Cloud ALM ‚Äì Change Management with a Demo Tenant: Your Step-by-Step Getting Started
entry.content:
SAP Cloud ALM (Application Lifecycle Management) is a modern, cloud-native platform developed by SAP to support the entire application lifecycle‚Äîfrom initial implementation and project planning to operations and continuous improvement. It‚Äôs designed for both cloud and hybrid environments, empowering businesses to gain visibility, control, and agility in managing their SAP landscapes.

In this comprehensive walkthrough, we‚Äôll guide you through the practical setup and usage of SAP Cloud ALM using a demo tenant. Whether you‚Äôre an SAP Basis consultant, implementation lead, or project manager, this tutorial is tailored to help you understand core elements like Implementation Projects, System Groups, Features, Transport Management, and Deployment Planning.

https://support.sap.com/en/alm/demo-systems/cloud-alm-demo-system.html?anchorId=section_1043771746

 

 

 

üë®‚Äçüíª For this demo, we‚Äôll be using the user Adam in the Cloud ALM tenant.

 

 

 

üß≠ Step 1: Navigating to the Implementation App

To begin, access the ‚ÄúImplementation‚Äù tab from the main SAP Cloud ALM dashboard.

 

 

 

üîó Navigate to: Implementation ‚Üí Projects and Setup

 

 

üõ†Ô∏è Step 2: Create and Configure Your Implementation Project

üëâ In the ‚ÄúProjects and Setup‚Äù section, click on ‚ÄúCreate Project‚Äù.
Provide a project name, a brief description, and select the appropriate product (e.g., SAP S/4HANA).

This setup enables structured tracking of implementation activities and aligns your technical tasks with business goals.

 

 

 

 

üß© Step 3: Assign System Landscapes Using System Groups

‚û°Ô∏è Go to the System Groups section.
üìå Enter a name for your group and select the relevant SAP product (e.g., SAP S/4HANA).
Assign each system (Development, Quality, and Production) to its respective role.

 

 

 

 

 

üí° System Groups help ensure a smooth flow of transports across your SAP landscape by logically organizing system roles.

üì¶ Step 4: Define a Deployment Plan

Navigate to the Deployment Plan area.

üóÇ Create a new deployment plan, associate it with your System Group, and specify relevant Release Versions.
This configuration allows you to coordinate when and how different features will be delivered across environments.

 

 

‚úîÔ∏è Once done, assign this plan to your implementation project.

 

 

üåü Step 5: Manage Features and Functional Enhancements

Open the Features tab and click ‚ÄúCreate Feature.‚Äù

 

 

A Feature in Cloud ALM is a unit of work or change. You can:

  • üîó Link it to a Requirement (business need).

 

  • üì¶ Attach a Release to group multiple features into one go-live bundle.

 

  • üß≠ Align it with the Deployment Plan for controlled rollout.

üìå Features track the end-to-end journey of a change‚Äîfrom planning to productive use.

üì§ Step 6: Assign or Create Transports for the Feature

Inside the feature, scroll to the Transports create section.

üõ† Click ‚ÄúCreate Transport‚Äù to initiate a transport request.

 

 

 

 

Once assigned, click ‚ÄúStart Implementation‚Äù to activate development.

 

 


The feature status updates to ‚ÄúIn Implementation.‚Äù

üîÅ Step 7: Release Transport Tasks and Generate TOCs

When development is complete, release the individual tasks within the transport in the Development system.

 

üåÄ Return to the Cloud ALM interface and click the ‚ÄúCopy‚Äù button in the Transports section to create a Transport of Copies (TOC).

 

 

‚úÖ TOCs allow early testing of changes in the Quality system without releasing the main transport prematurely.

  • A grey icon indicates TOC creation is in progress.

 

 

  • Once successful, the icon turns green, and the TOC is auto-scheduled for import to Quality.

 

üß™ Step 8: Initiate Testing in Quality System

After successful import of the TOC into Quality:

üß™ Click ‚ÄúHandover to Test‚Äù within the feature.
The status will change to ‚ÄúIn Testing‚Äù, signaling readiness for validation.

 

 

 

üöÄ Step 9: Release and Deploy the Main Transport

Once changes are validated:

  1. Click ‚ÄúRelease‚Äù to release the main TR from Development.

 

 

 

  1. Click ‚ÄúDeploy‚Äù to move the main TR into the Quality system.

 

üîÑ This approach ensures compliance with change management best practices.

üèÅ Step 10: Approve and Move to Production

After testing in Quality is complete:

  1. Update the feature status to ‚ÄúApprove for Production.‚Äù
  2.  

 

 

  1. It will now reflect as ‚ÄúReady for Production.‚Äù

 

  1. Click ‚ÄúDeploy‚Äù again to move the main transport into the Production system.

 

üìã Use the History tab to review changes, user activity, and timestamps for full traceability.

 

 

‚úÖ Conclusion

SAP Cloud ALM, when used via the demo tenant, provides a powerful sandbox environment to understand how lifecycle operations, project structures, and transport workflows are orchestrated in SAP.

By following this structured approach, you gain practical experience in:

  • Creating projects and system landscapes
  • Managing features and requirements
  • Orchestrating transport flows from Development to Production
  • Ensuring auditability and traceability with built-in monitoring

üéØ Whether you're preparing for a live customer implementation or upskilling on SAP Cloud ALM, this guide gives you a clear head start.

entry.title: Re: Performance DB SELECT * FOR ALL statement can be joined with SELECT statement at ... line ...
entry.content:
I faced similar issue while using FOR ALL ENTRIES statement. I was able to remove the CHECK Message by adding SORT statement after the SELECT statement.

SELECT old_vendor FROM zxxx_vendor_xxx INTO TABLE gt_pur_lfa1 
FOR ALL ENTRIES IN gt_ekorg WHERE old_vendor = gt_ekorg-lifnr.
IF sy-subrc = 0.
  SORT gt_pur_lfa1 BY old_vendor.
ENDIF.

entry.title: Identity and Access Management in SAP: Navigating SSO Across Web and On-Prem Landscapes
entry.content:
As explained in my latest post, managing Identity and Access Management (IAM) in SAP environments  is more crucial than ever. Beyond simply improving user experience, effective IAM ensures secure and consistent authentication mechanisms across both cloud and on-premise systems. At the heart of this strategy lies SAP Cloud Identity Services (SCI)‚Äîthe go-to solution for centralized identity management and streamlined Single Sign-On (SSO) in the SAP ecosystem.

SCI serves as the central interface for managing identity and access across SAP solutions. It plays a foundational role in enabling SSO while enforcing authentication policies uniformly across the landscape. Within the Secure Operations Map (SOM), SSO is positioned squarely in the "Authentication and Single Sign-On" domain, underlining its critical role in maintaining secure and reliable access throughout your SAP systems.

Authentication in the Context of the Secure Operations Map (SOM)

One Authentication Experience Across Web and On-Premise

A key advantage of SCI is its ability to support both cloud-based and on-premise authentication scenarios. For browser-based applications, SCI supports modern protocols such as SAML 2.0 and OpenID Connect (OIDC). These standards are widely adopted across the SAP ecosystem and allow organizations to integrate with various identity providers while benefiting from centralized policy enforcement. For those navigating protocol choices, you can explore the comparison further in this blog post.

When it comes to authentication to on-premise applications, things work differently. These clients communicate via Remote Function Calls (RFC) rather than HTTP, which means traditional SAML or OIDC-based SSO methods don‚Äôt apply. To extend SSO capabilities here, SAP recommends using Secure Login Client in combination with Secure Login Service (SLS). This setup leverages short-lived X.509 certificates that are issued based on SCI-authenticated identities. The benefit of this approach is that it allows organizations to reuse the same Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) mechanisms you‚Äôve implemented for web applications, ensuring a seamless and secure user experience across all access channels.

Single sign-on based on X.509 certificates ‚Äì Process flow

There are other options than using short lived certificates via SLS available as well. Organizations can opt for Kerberos tokens, which are especially suitable for Windows-based environments, or deploy local short-lived client certificates.

For those seeking a more technical view of how these components interact, SAP offers a reference architecture for authentication, including SCI‚Äôs integration with both cloud and on-premise systems.

Authentication Reference Architecture

What‚Äôs Next: From Access Risks to Business Risks

With the fundamentals of access management and SSO in place, the next step is to examine broader business risks in your SAP landscape. In upcoming posts, we‚Äôll shift focus to how these risks can be identified, analyzed, and contained using SAP Risk and Assurance Management (RAM)‚Äîa critical layer of protection beyond technical access controls.

entry.title: Cannot Perform MIGO After Changing and Restoring PO Release Strategy
entry.content:
Hello SAP Experts,

I need help with an issue we're facing after changing our Purchase Order (PO) release strategy.

Initial Setup (Before Change):

We had several release strategy levels based on PO value:

A1: < 50 million ‚Üí Approvers: 1A, 10

A2: > 50 million < 1 billion ‚Üí Approvers: 1A, 10, 1B

A3: >  1 billion ‚Üí Approvers: 1A, 10, 1B, 1C

We changed the release strategy to simplify it:

A1: ‚â• 0 ‚Üí Approvers: 1A, 10

After making this change, existing POs that were not yet released could not proceed because their original release strategy (e.g. A3) no longer existed.

So, I restored the A3 release strategy,  like before. Now, the PO can be released again, but when trying to do MIGO, we get the following error:

No goods receipt possible for purchase order 4010002627
Message no. M7036

We‚Äôve verified that:

The PO exists

The items are not deleted or blocked

There are no confirmation controls active

The PO has been released

Questions:

What should I do to running well MIGO with that PO number?
What is the best practice when modifying or simplifying release strategies with existing open POs?
Thank you in advance!

entry.title: Re: Cannot Perform MIGO After Changing and Restoring PO R...
entry.content:
Here are common causes and what to check:

  • In ME23N, check the item-level ‚ÄúGoods Receipt‚Äù indicator under the Delivery tab. It must be ticked.
  • Some PO types may restrict GR. Confirm that the document type allows GR.
  • Ensure the material is extended to the plant/storage location and is allowed for GR.
  • If the delivery date is in the past or future beyond tolerance, GR may be blocked.
  • Check if the stock type (e.g., quality inspection) is causing issues.
  • Even if not active, double-check that it‚Äôs blank or not enforcing confirmations.

If all of the above checks out, try debugging MIGO to see if the system is still referencing the old release strategy classification. Sometimes, a PO created under a now-deleted strategy retains internal flags that block GR‚Äîeven after restoration.

Also, check SAP notes 598342, 3335067 and  2291999

entry.title: SAP MDG: Custom Generic Class for developments
entry.content:
HI SCN Folks, 

Note:
01. There are several ways to implement it, and the blog that's written is one of the ways.
02. There are no screenshots attached related to SAP Logon & SAP MDG UI Screens.
03. In this blog, example which i taken the development of one of the Enhancement UIBB & a Method is GET_DATA.

Faced Problem:
Every time i used to call the below program for different placeholders & for different requirements. In short, making use of the same code again & again.

ZSU_MDG_CL_ENH_CUS_UIBB

DATA :
  lv_cr_number TYPE usmd_crequest,
  lv_crtype    TYPE usmd_crequest_type,
  lv_process   TYPE usmd_process.

DATA(lo_context) = cl_usmd_app_context=>get_context( ).

IF lo_context IS BOUND.
  CALL METHOD lo_context->get_attributes
    IMPORTING
      ev_crequest_id   = lv_cr_number
      ev_crequest_type = lv_crtype
      ev_process       = lv_process.
ENDIF.

IF lv_crtype EQ 'ZSUCRTYPE'.

      "Requirement Logic

ENDIF.

How to reduce this reusability? Please follow the below process

01. Create one custom class.
       ZSU_MDG_CL_GENERIC (Class)

02. Create one Static Method (Level), Public (Visibility) & Exporting Parameters.
        GET_CR_RELATED

  class-methods GET_CR_RELATED
    exporting
      !EO_MODEL type ref to IF_USMD_MODEL_EXT
      !EV_PARENT_PROCESS type USMD_PROCESS
      !EV_PROCESS type USMD_PROCESS
      !EV_WI_ID type SWW_WIID
      !EV_CREQUEST_ID type USMD_CREQUEST
      !EV_CREQUEST_TYPE type USMD_CREQUEST_TYPE
      !EV_CREQUEST_STEP type USMD_CREQUEST_APPSTEP
      !EV_CREQUEST_INDEX type USMD_CREQUEST_WFINDEX
      !EV_EDITION type USMD_EDITION
      !EV_OTC type USMD_OTC .


03. Now enter the below code in the method (Source Code). 

  method GET_CR_RELATED.

      DATA:
      lo_app_ctxt  TYPE REF TO  if_usmd_app_context.


    lo_app_ctxt = cl_usmd_app_context=>get_context( ).

    IF lo_app_ctxt IS BOUND.

      lo_app_ctxt->get_attributes(
       IMPORTING
         eo_model          =  eo_model
         ev_process        =  ev_process
         ev_wi_id          =  ev_wi_id
         ev_crequest_id    =  ev_crequest_id
         ev_crequest_type  =  ev_crequest_type
         ev_crequest_step  =  ev_crequest_step
         ev_crequest_index =  ev_crequest_index
         ev_otc            =  ev_otc
     ).
    ENDIF.

  endmethod.

Done with part of this class (ZSU_MDG_CL_GENERIC). 

Now It's time to use it in any development placeholder; in this blog, implementing it in (ZSU_MDG_CL_ENH_CUS_UIBB).

  DATA: lv_creq_type TYPE usmd_crequest_type,
          lv_wf_step   TYPE usmd_crequest_appstep.


    CALL METHOD ZSU_MDG_CL_GENERIC=>get_cr_related
      IMPORTING
        ev_crequest_type = lv_creq_type  " Type of Change Request
        ev_crequest_step = lv_wf_step.

IF lv_crtype EQ 'ZSUCRTYPE'.
       IF lv_wf_step = '00'.

      "Requirement Logic

ENDIF.
ENDIF.

 

SAP Master Data Governance 

Thank You, 
Sandeep Suggu.
SAP Community Profile | SAP Profile | LinkedIn

entry.title: Re: S4 Public cloud BOP is not working as expected
entry.content:
Even though you've sorted by document number in ascending order, confirmation priority in BOP is driven by the confirmation strategy and segment execution order, not just the sort sequence. Here‚Äôs what could be causing the mismatch

  • If your segment is assigned to a strategy like Gain or Improve, it may prioritize previously confirmed orders‚Äîeven if they‚Äôre newer.
  • Sorting within a segment only affects that segment. If multiple segments exist under the same strategy, the system may not respect the sort order across them.
  • AP may internally treat document 21 as ‚Äúolder‚Äù due to timestamps or scheduling lines, even if its number is higher.


What you can try is

  • Use Win strategy if you want strict first-come-first-serve behavior. Avoid Gain or Improve if they allow newer documents to retain confirmations.
  • Go to Configure BOP Segment app. Confirm that sorting is set to ascending by document number. Make sure this segment is the first in execution order under the strategy.
  • In Schedule BOP Run, ensure the job is not marked as simulation. Only execution mode updates the actual order confirmations.


For information, if you're using multiple segments under the same strategy, SAP prioritizes them in the order they appear. So even if your sorting is correct, a segment with broader selection criteria might override it. You can read more about this behavior in SAP‚Äôs aATP documentation here

entry.title: Re: How to read/write SAP CPI Datastore from Groovy
entry.content:
@mathias_rohland As SAP (and the blog author) mentioned in the first comment above, usage of these classes are discouraged as they are only internal (non-public APIs). So if you worry about the wildcard imports you should also worry about potential changes in the APIs in the future. üôÇ 

This is a pity, I would also like to use these classes as doing a lookup to the datastore Odata API in the IFlow (e.g. to check if a specific data store exists) produces a chargeable message, inflates the IFlow layout, etc.

But what you at least can do: use the class from the java.net package (like java.net.HttpURLConnection) to open a connection to the Datastore OData API from within your script, so that at least you don't have to use the standard IFlow utilities if that is less convenient for some reason. 

Philippe

entry.title: Re: I am simulating a jms queue using 2 iflows in SAP int...
entry.content:
Hi, without seeing your Iflows, I can only guess. Do you have an exception subprocess in your process? If so, does the exception process end with a "message end", "error end" or "escalation end" symbol? You must use "error end" if you want to keep the entries in the JSM queue for retry.

Philippe
